review.title: Aggregating partial rankings with applications to peer grading in massive online open courses
review.abstract: We investigate the potential of using ordinal peer grading for the evaluation of students in massive online open courses (MOOCs). According to such grading schemes, each student receives a few assignments (by other students) which she has to rank. Then, a global ranking (possibly translated into numerical scores) is produced by combining the individual ones. This is a novel application area for social choice concepts and methods where the important problem to be solved is as follows: how should the assignments be distributed so that the collected individual rankings can be easily merged into a global one that is as close as possible to the ranking that represents the relative performance of the students in the assignment? Our main theoretical result suggests that using very simple ways to distribute the assignments so that each student has to rank only $k$ of them, a Borda-like aggregation method can recover a $1-O(1/k)$ fraction of the true ranking when each student correctly ranks the assignments she receives. Experimental results strengthen our analysis further and also demonstrate that the same method is extremely robust even when students have imperfect capabilities as graders. We believe that our results provide strong evidence that ordinal peer grading can be a highly effective and scalable solution for evaluation in MOOCs.

metadata.title: Aggregating partial rankings with applications to peer grading in massive online open courses∗

sections.text: After these evaluation programs, each student receives a few tasks (from other students) that he or she has to rank. Then, a global ranking (possibly translated into numerical values) is created by combining the individual scores. This is a new application for social choice concepts and methods, where the main problem to solve is this: How should the tasks be distributed so that the individual rankings collected can easily be merged into a global one that is as close as possible to the ranking that represents the relative performance of the students in the task? Our main theoretical finding suggests that by using very simple methods for distributing the tasks so that each student only has to rank k of them, a Borda-like aggregation method can restore a fraction of the true ranking if each student grades the tasks correctly. Experimental results further strengthen our analysis and also show that the same method is extremely robust, even if the students have imperfect skills, such as grades that we believe our colleagues can provide a good rating.
